headline: What US-Ukraine minerals deal means for Putin | World News | Sky News
context: The minerals deal may be good news for Ukraine, but it is not necessarily bad news for Russia.
That's because a deal with Volodymyr Zelenskyy doesn't preclude a deal with Vladimir Putin.

annotations.paragraph: It's important to remember there are three separate strands of negotiations that Donald Trump is juggling here.
annotations.reason: This provides context about the complexity of negotiations involving the US, Ukraine, and Russia.

annotations.paragraph: Follow live updates: US and Ukraine sign 'historic' deal
annotations.reason: This is a prompt for live updates and does not contribute new information to the article.

annotations.paragraph: This deal is the result of one strand - Washington's contacts with Kyiv, which the White House has pursued to ensure America gets something back for its military support of Ukraine.
annotations.reason: This explains the motivation behind the US-Ukraine deal, directly related to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Then there are peace talks themselves, where Donald Trump has proposed what appears to be a very one-sided peace plan in favour of Moscow. For now, that hasn't changed.
annotations.reason: This provides relevant context about the peace talks and their implications for the US-Ukraine deal.

annotations.paragraph: And the final strand is the US-Russia strand, where the US president is chasing a rapprochement with Moscow.
annotations.reason: This highlights the US's ongoing diplomatic efforts with Russia, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: There is some crossover between the strands - the security guarantees for Ukraine are a case in point.
annotations.reason: This paragraph hints at the interconnectedness of security and economic deals, relevant to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Please use Chrome browser for a more accessible video player
annotations.reason: This is a technical instruction unrelated to the article's content.

annotations.paragraph: US companies on the ground in eastern Ukraine is not exactly the security guarantee Mr Zelenskyy had in mind, but I think it will give the Kremlin pause for thought when it comes to continuing its military campaign.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides analysis on the implications of US presence in Ukraine, relevant to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Because if it did, it would almost certainly scupper the rapprochement with Washington.
annotations.reason: This sentence suggests potential diplomatic consequences, relevant to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: There has been lots of talk of business deals and joint economic cooperation between the US and Russia as a result of their negotiations and I'm sure both parties still intend that to happen.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses potential future economic cooperation, relevant to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Trump's business background suggests he will try to get as much out of this situation as possible, and I think Russia will as well.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides speculative commentary on potential actions by Trump and Russia, which is not directly related to the minerals deal.
This is a promotional line unrelated to the article's content.

annotations.paragraph: Listen to The World with Richard Engel and Yalda Hakim every Wednesday
annotations.reason: This is a promotional line unrelated to the article's content.
This is a promotional line unrelated to the article's content.

annotations.paragraph: So I think the Kremlin could see this as an opportunity to extract more from the negotiations they're involved in, perhaps portraying it as a concession on their part in order to impose more conditions.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides analysis on how the Kremlin might leverage the situation, which is relevant to the article's focus on the implications of the minerals deal.

annotations.paragraph: They might say, for example, that American business interests are a security guarantee enough for Kyiv, and then use that argument to get US backing for their opposition to a real security guarantee in the form of European peacekeepers.
annotations.reason: This paragraph speculates on potential political maneuvers related to the minerals deal, providing context on how it might be leveraged in international relations.

annotations.paragraph: Or they might use it to reinforce other demands, like sanctions relief, recognition of Crimea or US support for Russia's readmittance to the G7.
annotations.reason: This paragraph continues to explore the geopolitical implications of the deal, offering insight into possible Russian strategies.

annotations.paragraph: Donald Trump may be the master dealmaker, but Moscow are the masters of protecting their own interests and this minerals deal is unlikely to prevent that.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a general statement about Russia's ability to protect its interests, which does not add specific new information about the minerals deal.
